unnormalised: The Delhi Jal Board (DJB) announced revised water tariffs effective 01/04/2024. Consumers using up to 20,000 liters will continue to receive free water, a scheme benefiting an estimated 40% of households. However, usage exceeding 20KL will be charged at a rate of ₹28.78 per 1000 liters for the next 10KL.
normalised: The D-J-B announced revised water tariffs effective first april two thousand and twenty four. Consumers using up to twenty thousand liters will continue to receive free water, a scheme benefiting an estimated forty percent of households. However, usage exceeding twenty K-L will be charged at a rate of rupee twenty eight point seventy eight per one thousand liters for the next ten K-L.

unnormalised: For consumption between 30,001 and 50,000 liters, the rate increases to ₹41.22 per kiloliter, while usage beyond 50,000 liters will be levied at a higher rate of ₹55.13 per 1000 liters. DJB officials stated the revision aims to promote responsible water usage and address rising operational costs. The average household in Delhi consumes approximately 150 liters/day, so the changes are expected to impact larger families and those with leaky pipes.
normalised: For consumption between thirty thousand and one and fifty thousand liters, the rate increases to rupee forty one point twenty two per kiloliter, while usage beyond fifty thousand liters will be levied at a higher rate of rupee fifty five point thirteen per one thousand liters. D-J-B officials stated the revision aims to promote responsible water usage and address rising operational costs. The average household in Delhi consumes approximately one hundred and fifty liters per day, so the changes are expected to impact larger families and those with leaky pipes.

unnormalised: Electricity consumption is also under scrutiny. BSES Yamuna Power Limited (BYPL) reported that peak demand reached 7409 MW during the summer months. To encourage energy conservation, BYPL is offering a rebate of ₹1.50 per unit for consumers who reduce their consumption by 10% compared to the same period last year. This initiative hopes to lessen the strain on the grid and lower individual electricity bills, particularly given that a standard AC unit consumes approximately 1.5 kW per hour.
normalised: Electricity consumption is also under scrutiny. B-S-E-S Yamuna Power Limited (B-Y-P-L) reported that peak demand reached seven thousand four hundred and nine M-W during the summer months. To encourage energy conservation, B-Y-P-L is offering a rebate of rupee one point fifty per unit for consumers who reduce their consumption by ten percent compared to the same period last year. This initiative hopes to lessen the strain on the grid and lower individual electricity bills, particularly given that a standard A-C unit consumes approximately one point five k-W per hour.

unnormalised: Citizens can monitor their consumption through the DJB and BYPL apps. These apps provide detailed breakdowns of water and electricity usage, helping consumers identify areas for potential savings. Understanding your daily consumption patterns – whether it's 500 liters of water or 10 kWh of electricity – is the first step towards efficient resource management and lower monthly expenses.
normalised: Citizens can monitor their consumption through the D-J-B and B-Y-P-L apps. These apps provide detailed breakdowns of water and electricity usage, helping consumers identify areas for potential savings. Understanding your daily consumption patterns – whether it's five hundred liters of water or ten k-W-h of electricity – is the first step towards efficient resource management and lower monthly expenses.
